Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who would not take kindly to your borrowing his property. Is it appropriate for you to borrow the speedboat in order to warn the tourists about the storm?
a1: the principle of beneficence dictates that we should do good and avoid harm. in this case, borrowing the speedboat is the best way to ensure the safety of the tourists, and therefore it is the morally correct thing to do.
question: Do you agree with the second answer from the blue character (justification)? (#2)

title: Shower
q0: You are planning to attend a luncheon this afternoon, and before you go   you will need to take a shower. You have some yard work that you would like to do before then, and doing this yard will cause you to perspire a fair amount. If you shower before you do your yard work you will have to take another shower before the luncheon. At the present time you could enjoy taking a shower. At the same time, you have a very strong commitment to lowering your water bill and to showering no more than once a day. Would you shower before doing your yard work in order to enjoy a shower now?
a1: showering twice in one day would be a waste of water, and i am trying to be conscious of my water usage in order to lower my bill. enjoying a shower later on is not worth wasting water now.
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Euthanasia
q0: You are the leader of a small group of soldiers. You are on   your way back from a completed mission deep in enemy territory when one of your men has stepped in trap that has been set by the enemy and is badly injured. The trap is connected to a radio device that by now has alerted the enemy to your presence. They will soon be on their way. If the enemy finds your injured man they will torture him and kill him. He begs you not to leave him behind, but if you try to take him with you your entire group will be captured. The only way to prevent this injured soldier from being tortured is to shoot him yourself. Is it appropriate for you to shoot this soldier in order to prevent him from being tortured by the enemy?
a1: shooting the solder to protect him from torture is the most humane action, as it is more important than anything else.
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Sophie
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. At the enemy’s headquarters is a doctor who performs painful experiments on humans that inevitably lead to death. He intends to perform experiments on one of your children, but he will allow you to choose which of your children will be experimented upon. You have twenty-four hours to bring one of your children to his laboratory. If you refuse to bring one of your children to his laboratory he will find them both and experiment on both of them. Is it appropriate for you to bring one of your children to the laboratory in order to avoid having them both die?
a1: the reason is that, by bringing one child to the laboratory, you are giving that child a chance to live. even though the experiments are painful and will inevitably lead to death, there is at least a chance that the child will survive. if you do not bring either child to the laboratory, then both children will definitely die. therefore, it is better to bring one child to the laboratory than to not bring any child at all.
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Lost Wallet
q0: You are walking down the street when you come across a wallet lying   on the ground. You open the wallet and find that it contains several hundred dollars in cash as well the owner’s driver’s license. From the credit cards and other items in the wallet it’s very clear that the wallet’s owner is wealthy. You, on the other hand, have been hit by hard times recently and could really use some extra money. You consider sending the wallet back to the owner without the cash, keeping the cash for yourself. Is it appropriate for you to keep the money you found in the wallet in order to have more money for yourself?
a1: stelaling is a crime; if you take money from a lost wallet, you're risking prosecution & harming someone financially.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Jogging
q0: You intend to accomplish two things this afternoon: going for a jog and   doing some paperwork. In general you prefer to get your work done before you exercise. The weather is nice at the moment, but the weather forecast says that in a couple of hours it will start to rain. You very much dislike jogging in the rain, but you don’t care what the weather is like while you do paperwork. Would you do your paperwork now with the intention of jogging in a couple of hours in order to get your work done before you exercise?
a1: i'll do the paperwork first and wait to go jog until the skies are clear, since i don't like running in wet weather.

title: Standard Trolley
q0: You are at the wheel of a runaway trolley quickly approaching a fork   in the tracks. On the tracks extending to the left is a group of five railway workmen. On the tracks extending to the right is a single railway workman. If you do nothing the trolley will proceed to the left, causing the deaths of the five workmen. The only way to avoid the deaths of these workmen is to hit a switch on your dashboard that will cause the trolley to proceed to the right, causing the death of the single workman. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen?
a1: the trolley will cause the deaths of five workmen if it proceeds to the left. the only way to avoid the deaths of these workmen is to hit the switch and cause the trolley to go to the right, resulting in the death of the single workman. although this is tragic, it is better than the alternative of five deaths.

title: Three-for-Seven Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. title: Illegal Lunch
q0: You are a lawyer working on a big case. The judge presiding over   the trial happens to be someone you knew from law school. The two of you were rather friendly back then, but now, decades later, it seems that your old friend barely remembers you. You’re quite sure that if you were to talk to him over lunch, you could jog his memory and he would begin to see you as an old buddy, which would be very good for your work on this case. It’s illegal for judges and lawyers working on the same case to meet socially. Is it appropriate for you to meet with this judge socially in order to help you win your case?
a1: socializing with the judge presiding over your case would be a clear violation of the ethical principle of "judicial impartiality." this principle requires that judges maintain an impartial attitude towards all parties in a case, and avoid any behavior that could create the appearance of bias. if you were to meet with the judge outside of court, it would give the appearance that you are trying to improperly influence the judge's decision in your favor. this could undermine public confidence in the fairness of the judicial system, and could lead to your case being overturned on appeal.

title: Guarded Speedboat
q0: While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside   dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. title: Grandson
q0: A young boy is visiting his grandmother for the weekend. Usually she gives   him a gift of a few dollars when he arrives, but this time she doesn’t. He asks her why not and she says something about how he doesn’t write her as many letters as he used to. Angered by this, the boy decides to play a trick on her. While his grandmother is busy cooking he removes a handful of pills from the medicine cabinet and puts them in his grandmother’s teapot. Later that night, she makes her tea, and the dissolved pills make her sick. In the morning she is dead. Was it appropriate for this boy to put pills in his grandmother’s teapot in order to play a trick on her?

title: Broken VCR
q0: You have brought your broken VCR to the local repair shop. The woman   working at the shop tells you that it will cost you about $100 to have it fixed. You noticed in the paper that morning that the electronics shop next door is having a sale on VCR’s and that a certain new VCR which is slightly better than your old one is on sale for $100. Would you have your old VCR fixed in order to avoid spending money on a new one?
a1: there are a few reasons why i wouldn't have my old vcr fixed. first, $100 is a lot of money to spend on repairing an old vcr when you can get a new, slightly better one for the same price. second, even if the repair is successful, there's no guarantee that the vcr will last for very much longer before it breaks down again. third, given that vcr's are becoming increasingly obsolete, it might be difficult to find someone who is able to repair it properly. for these reasons, i would prefer to spend my money on a new vcr.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Illegal Lunch
q0: You are a lawyer working on a big case. The judge presiding over   the trial happens to be someone you knew from law school. The two of you were rather friendly back then, but now, decades later, it seems that your old friend barely remembers you. You’re quite sure that if you were to talk to him over lunch, you could jog his memory and he would begin to see you as an old buddy, which would be very good for your work on this case. It’s illegal for judges and lawyers working on the same case to meet socially. Is it appropriate for you to meet with this judge socially in order to help you win your case?
a1: judges are supposed to be impartial and objective. if they meet with one of the lawyers involved in a case socially, it could create the appearance of impropriety or partiality. even if the judge is just trying to be friendly, it could be seen as favoritism. it's better to avoid any potential conflict of interest or appearance of impropriety.

title: Sophie
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. At the enemy’s headquarters is a doctor who performs painful experiments on humans that inevitably lead to death. He intends to perform experiments on one of your children, but he will allow you to choose which of your children will be experimented upon. You have twenty-four hours to bring one of your children to his laboratory. If you refuse to bring one of your children to his laboratory he will find them both and experiment on both of them. Is it appropriate for you to bring one of your children to the laboratory in order to avoid having them both die?
a1: the enemy doctor's experiments are inevitably fatal, so if both children are subjected to them, they will both die. by bringing only one child to the laboratory, there is a chance that child will survive. therefore, it is more rational to bring only one child to the laboratory in order to avoid having them both die.

title: Vaccine Policy
q0: You work for the Bureau of Health, a government agency. You are deciding   whether or not your agency should encourage the use of a certain recently developed vaccine. title: Five-for-Seven Trolley
q0: You are at the wheel of a runaway trolley quickly approaching a fork   in the tracks. On the tracks extending to the left is a group of five railway workmen. On the tracks extending to the right is a group of seven railway workmen. If you do nothing the trolley will proceed to the left, causing the deaths of the five workmen. The only way to save these workmen is to hit a switch on your dashboard that will cause the trolley to proceed to the right, causing the deaths of the seven workmen on the other side. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen?
a1: the trolley problem is a thought experiment in ethics first introduced by philosopher philippa foot in 1967. the general form of the problem is as follows: there is a runaway trolley barreling down a track towards five workers who will be killed if the trolley proceeds on its current course. there is a switch nearby that will cause the trolley to instead diverge onto a different track where only one worker will be killed. is it morally permissible for a bystander to flip the switch and cause the trolley to kill the one worker instead of the five?  the trolley problem is intended to test our intuitions about moral responsibility and the value of human life. many people believe that it is morally permissible to flip the switch in order to save the lives of the five workers. after all, the one worker who will be killed if the switch is flipped is not responsible for the trolley being on the track in the first place, and the five workers who will be killed if the switch is not flipped are not responsible for the trolley being on the track either. furthermore, the death of one worker seems like a much lesser tragedy than the death of five workers.  however, there are also some people who believe that it is not morally permissible
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Smother for dollars
q0: You are in hospital lounge waiting to visit a sick friend. A young   man sitting next to you explains that his father is very ill. The doctors believe that he has a week to live at most. He explains further that his father has a substantial life insurance policy that expires at midnight. If his father dies before midnight, this young man will receive a very large sum of money. He says that the money would mean a great deal to him and that no good will come from his father’s living a few more days. He offers you half a million dollars to go up to his father’s room and smother his father with a pillow. Is it appropriate for you to kill this man’s father in order to get money for yourself and this young man?
a1: it is difficult to make a general statement about whether or not it is appropriate to kill someone for money, because it depends on the specific circumstances. if you know the young man well and you are confident that he is not simply trying to inherit his father's money early, then you may be more inclined to agree to his request. alternatively, if you are in dire need of the money, you may be more likely to agree to the plan. however, if you are not comfortable with the idea of killing someone, even for money, then you would probably not agree to the young man's request.

title: Hard Times
q0: You are the head of a poor household in a developing country. Your   crops have failed for the second year in a row, and it appears that you have no way to feed your family. Your sons, ages eight and ten, are too young to go off to the city where there jobs, but your daughter could fare better. You know a man from your village who lives in the city and who makes sexually explicit films featuring small children such as your daughter. He tells you that in one year of working in his studio your daughter could earn enough money to keep your family fed for several growing seasons. Is it appropriate for you to employ your daughter in the child pornography industry in order to feed your family?
a1: the child pornography industry is a highly exploitative industry that takes advantage of vulnerable children. the children who appear in these films are often from poor or disadvantaged backgrounds, and they are often coerced or forced into participating. the industry also exposes children to graphic and sexual material that can be damaging to their development.  therefore, while it may be necessary to do what is necessary to feed one's family, there are also serious ethical concerns about employing a child in the child pornography industry.

title: Standard Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there is a single patient. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to avoid the deaths of these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three patients. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the single patient, causing his death. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: the utilitarian approach would argue that the most ethical decision is the one that results in the greatest good for the greatest number of people. in this case, that would mean hitting the switch in order to save the three patients. even though doing so would result in the death of the single patient, that is outweighed by the fact that three lives would be saved.

title: Lifeboat 2
q0: You are on a cruise ship when there is a fire on board,   and the ship has to be abandoned. The lifeboats are carrying many more people than they were designed to carry. q0: You are negotiating with a powerful and determined terrorist who is about to   set off a bomb in a crowded area. Your one advantage is that you have his teenage son in your custody. title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. Once you figure out which substance is the vaccine you can use it to save millions of lives. You have with you two people who are under your care, and the only way to identify the vaccine is to inject each of these people with one of the two substances. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of these people with a deadly injection in order to identify a vaccine that will save millions of lives?
a1: the reason is that the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the cost of the one person's life. in this case, the cost is just one person's life, but the benefits are potentially millions of lives saved. so, from a utilitarian perspective, it is morally permissible to kill one person in order to save many others.

title: Guarded Speedboat
q0: While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside   dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who has hired a fiercely loyal guard to make sure that no one uses his boat without permission. To get to the speedboat you will have to lie to the guard. Is it appropriate for you to lie to the guard in order to borrow the speedboat and warn the tourists about the storm?
a1: the reason why it would be appropriate for you to lie in this situation is because there is a greater good that you are trying to achieve by warning the tourists about the storm. lying in this situation would be considered a "white lie," which is a lie that is told in order to prevent harm or protect someone from getting hurt. in this case, the white lie would be told in order to protect the tourists from the potentially harmful effects of the storm.

title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?

title: Lost Wallet
q0: You are walking down the street when you come across a wallet lying   on the ground. title: Guarded Speedboat
q0: While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside   dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. title: Lawrence of Arabia
q0: You are the leader of a small army that consists of warriors from   two tribes, the hill tribe and the river tribe. You belong to neither tribe. During the night a hill tribesman got into an argument with a river tribesman and murdered him. The river tribe will attack the hill tribe unless the murderer is put to death, but the hill tribe refuses to kill one of its own warriors. The only way for you to avoid a war between the two tribes that will costs hundreds of lives is to publicly execute the murderer by cutting off is head with your sword. Is it appropriate for you to cut off this man’s head in order to prevent the two tribes from fighting a war that will cost hundreds of lives?
a1: the leader is trying to prevent a war between the two tribes, which would cost hundreds of lives. by executing the murderer, the leader is sending a message that violence will not be tolerated and that the two tribes need to resolve their differences peacefully.

title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. One day, while at school, your water breaks. You run to the girls locker room and hide for several hours while you deliver the baby. You are sure that you are not prepared to care for this baby. You think to yourself that it would be such a relief to simply clean up the mess you’ve made in the locker room, wrap the baby in some towels, throw the baby in the dumpster behind the school, and act as if nothing had ever happened. Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?
a1: there are a number of reasons why this would not be an appropriate solution to the situation. first, it would be incredibly difficult for the young mother to go through with such an act. the act of delivering a baby is an intense and emotional experience, and it is likely that the mother would feel a strong bond with her child immediately after birth. it would be very difficult for her to simply discard the baby in a dumpster after going through such an experience.  additionally, throwing the baby in the dumpster would be incredibly dangerous for the child. the baby would be exposed to the elements and could easily die of exposure or be injured by being thrown around in the dumpster.  finally, it is important to consider the legal implications of such an act. if the mother is caught, she could be charged with child abandonment or even murder. this could result in a prison sentence and a criminal record, which would negatively impact the rest of her life.  in conclusion, there are a number of reasons why it would not be appropriate for the fifteen year-old girl to throw her baby in the dumpster in order to move on with her life.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Hired Rapist
q0: You have been dissatisfied with your marriage for several years. It is your   distinct impression that your wife no longer appreciates you. title: Lifeboat 2
q0: You are on a cruise ship when there is a fire on board,   and the ship has to be abandoned. The lifeboats are carrying many more people than they were designed to carry. The lifeboat you’re in is sitting dangerously low in the water—a few inches lower and it will sink. The seas start to get rough, and the boat begins to fill with water. If nothing is done it will sink before the rescue boats arrive and everyone on board will die. However, there is an injured person who will not survive in any case. If you throw that person overboard the boat will stay afloat and the remaining passengers will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to throw this person overboard in order to save the lives of the remaining passengers?
a1: the scenario you describe is a variation of the "trolley problem," a thought experiment in ethics that has been debated by philosophers for centuries. the basic question is whether it is ever morally permissible to kill one person in order to save the lives of others.  there are a variety of ways to approach this problem, but one common approach is to consider the intentions of the person who is considering killing the one person. if the intention is to save as many lives as possible, then it might be morally permissible to kill the one person. however, if the intention is simply to save the life of the person who is in the lifeboat, then it is not morally permissible to kill the one person.

title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. Once you figure out which substance is the vaccine you can use it to save millions of lives. You have with you two people who are under your care, and the only way to identify the vaccine is to inject each of these people with one of the two substances. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of these people with a deadly injection in order to identify a vaccine that will save millions of lives?
a1: the reason is simple: the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the costs. by vaccinating millions of people, you will save far more lives than you will lose by injecting one person with the deadly substance. in other words, the net benefit of the vaccine is positive, and so it is morally permissible to use it, even if it means killing one person in the process.

q0: You are the leader of a small group of soldiers. title: Sophie
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. title: Illegal Lunch

The trunk of your car, which you’ve lined with plastic to catch the mud from the plants, will hold most of the plants you’ve purchased. You could bring all the plants home in one trip, but this would require putting some of the plants in the back seat as well as in the trunk. By putting some of the plants in the back seat you will ruin your fine leather upholstery which would cost thousands of dollars to replace. Would you make two trips home in order to avoid ruining the upholstery of your car?
a1: the plants are not worth more than the upholstery in my car, so it is not worth risking ruining the upholstery for the sake of saving time.

title: Smother for dollars

title: Vaccine Policy
q0: You work for the Bureau of Health, a government agency. You are deciding   whether or not your agency should encourage the use of a certain recently developed vaccine. The vast majority of people who take the vaccine develop an immunity to a certain deadly disease, but a very small number of people who take the vaccine will actually get the disease that the vaccine is designed to prevent. All the available evidence, which is very strong, suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to direct your agency to encourage the use of this vaccine in order to promote national health?
a1: the reason is that, while there is a very small chance that someone may get the disease from the vaccine, the chances of getting the disease without being vaccinated are much higher. therefore, it is in the best interest of public health to encourage people to take the vaccine.

title: Errands

The man explains that he has had an accident while hiking and asks you to take him to a nearby hospital. Your initial inclination is to help this man, who will probably lose his leg if he does not get to the hospital soon. However, if you give this man a lift, his blood will ruin the leather upholstery of your car. Is it appropriate for you to leave this man by the side of the road in order to preserve your leather upholstery?
a1: it would be morally wrong to leave this man by the side of the road, as he will likely lose his leg if he does not receive medical attention soon. the preservation of your car's leather upholstery is not a morally justifiable reason to abandon someone in need.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. title: Sophie
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. At the enemy’s headquarters is a doctor who performs painful experiments on humans that inevitably lead to death. He intends to perform experiments on one of your children, but he will allow you to choose which of your children will be experimented upon. You have twenty-four hours to bring one of your children to his laboratory. If you refuse to bring one of your children to his laboratory he will find them both and experiment on both of them. Is it appropriate for you to bring one of your children to the laboratory in order to avoid having them both die?
a1: there are a few reasons why this would not be the right thing to do. first, it would be incredibly traumatic for the child that is brought to the laboratory and subjected to the experiments. second, even if the child survived the experiments, they would likely be left with physical and psychological scars that would last a lifetime. finally, it is possible that both children would be killed anyway, even if you did bring one to the laboratory. in short, the risks far outweigh the potential benefits, and it is not worth sacrificing one child to save the other.

title: Hired Rapist

title: Hard Times
q0: You are the head of a poor household in a developing country. Your   crops have failed for the second year in a row, and it appears that you have no way to feed your family. You know a man from your village who lives in the city and who makes sexually explicit films featuring small children such as your daughter. He tells you that in one year of working in his studio your daughter could earn enough money to keep your family fed for several growing seasons. q0: You are at the wheel of a runaway trolley quickly approaching a fork   in the tracks. On the tracks extending to the left is a group of five railway workmen. title: Three-for-Seven Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there are seven patients. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to save these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three people. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the seven patients, causing their deaths. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: the reason is that the three patients in the first room will die if the switch is not hit, while the seven patients in the second room will only die if the switch is hit. therefore, hitting the switch will save three lives and result in the death of seven people.

title: Computer
q0: You are looking to buy a new computer. At the moment the computer   that you want costs $1000. A friend who knows the computer industry has told you that this computer’s price will drop to $500 next month. If you wait until next month to buy your new computer you will have to use your old computer for a few weeks longer than you would like to. Nevertheless you will be able to do everything you need to do using your old computer during that time. Would you use your old computer for a few more weeks in order to save $500 on the purchase of a new computer?

title: Lifeboat 2
q0: You are on a cruise ship when there is a fire on board,   and the ship has to be abandoned. The lifeboats are carrying many more people than they were designed to carry. The lifeboat you’re in is sitting dangerously low in the water—a few inches lower and it will sink. The seas start to get rough, and the boat begins to fill with water. If nothing is done it will sink before the rescue boats arrive and everyone on board will die. However, there is an injured person who will not survive in any case. If you throw that person overboard the boat will stay afloat and the remaining passengers will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to throw this person overboard in order to save the lives of the remaining passengers?
a1: the reason is that the person who is injured is going to die anyway, so their death will not make any difference to the outcome. the only difference is that if they are not thrown overboard, everyone on the lifeboat will die. therefore, it is more important to save the lives of the other people on the lifeboat than it is to preserve the life of the injured person.

title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. One day, while at school, your water breaks. You run to the girls locker room and hide for several hours while you deliver the baby. You are sure that you are not prepared to care for this baby. You think to yourself that it would be such a relief to simply clean up the mess you’ve made in the locker room, wrap the baby in some towels, throw the baby in the dumpster behind the school, and act as if nothing had ever happened. Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?
a1: there are a number of reasons why it would not be appropriate to abandon your baby in a dumpster. first and foremost, it would be incredibly harmful to the baby. babies are very vulnerable and need constant care and attention in order to survive. if you were to abandon your baby in a dumpster, they would be at risk of exposure to the elements, dehydration, and being crushed or suffocated.  additionally, abandoning your baby would be incredibly harmful to you as well. it would be very difficult to cope with the guilt and trauma of knowing that you had abandoned your own child. this could lead to mental health problems such as depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder.
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Crying Baby
q0: Enemy soldiers have taken over your village. They have orders to kill all   remaining civilians. You and some of your townspeople have sought refuge in the cellar of a large house. title: Reversed Turnips

title: Errands
q0: You need to go to the bakery in the morning and the furniture   store in the afternoon. You also need to go to the camera shop at some point. title: Three-for-Seven Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there are seven patients. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to save these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three people. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the seven patients, causing their deaths. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: the reason is that the number of lives saved (three) is greater than the number of lives lost (seven). in other words, the utilitarianism principle of "the greatest good for the greatest number" applies in this case.
question: Do you agree with the second answer from the blue character (justification)? (#2)

title: Illegal Lunch
q0: You are a lawyer working on a big case. The judge presiding over   the trial happens to be someone you knew from law school. The two of you were rather friendly back then, but now, decades later, it seems that your old friend barely remembers you. You’re quite sure that if you were to talk to him over lunch, you could jog his memory and he would begin to see you as an old buddy, which would be very good for your work on this case. It’s illegal for judges and lawyers working on the same case to meet socially. Is it appropriate for you to meet with this judge socially in order to help you win your case?
a1: it is not appropriate because it would be a violation of the code of professional responsibility, which prohibits lawyers from engaging in ex parte communications with judges. ex parte communications are communications between a lawyer and a judge that are not in the presence of the other party or their lawyers. these types of communications can give the lawyer an unfair advantage in the case.

title: Footbridge
q0: A runaway trolley is heading down the tracks toward five workmen who will   be killed if the trolley proceeds on its present course. You are on a footbridge over the tracks, in between the approaching trolley and the five workmen. Next to you on this footbridge is a stranger who happens to be very large. The only way to save the lives of the five workmen is to push this stranger off the bridge and onto the tracks below where his large body will stop the trolley. The stranger will die if you do this, but the five workmen will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to push the stranger on to the tracks in order to save the five workmen?

title: Guarded Speedboat
q0: While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside   dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who has hired a fiercely loyal guard to make sure that no one uses his boat without permission. To get to the speedboat you will have to lie to the guard. Is it appropriate for you to lie to the guard in order to borrow the speedboat and warn the tourists about the storm?
a1: the reasons for this are twofold. first, lying is generally only wrong if it results in harm to another person. in this case, lying to the guard is the only way to ensure that the tourists are warned about the storm and thus avoid harm. second, even if lying to the guard does result in some harm to him (e.g. he loses his job), that harm is outweighed by the good that you will do by warning the tourists about the storm.

title: Country Road

title: Sophie
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. At the enemy’s headquarters is a doctor who performs painful experiments on humans that inevitably lead to death. He intends to perform experiments on one of your children, but he will allow you to choose which of your children will be experimented upon. You have twenty-four hours to bring one of your children to his laboratory. If you refuse to bring one of your children to his laboratory he will find them both and experiment on both of them. Is it appropriate for you to bring one of your children to the laboratory in order to avoid having them both die?
a1: there are a few reasons why this is not appropriate. first, it is not guaranteed that bringing one child to the laboratory will actually avoid having them both die. the doctor may still experiment on both children even if you bring one of them to the laboratory. second, even if bringing one child to the laboratory does avoid having them both die, it is still effectively killing one child in order to save the other. this is not an ethically acceptable option. finally, there is the possibility that neither child will die if you refuse to bring one of them to the laboratory. this is a risk you have to take, but it is possible that both children will be spared if you do not cooperate with the doctor.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Illegal Lunch
q0: You are a lawyer working on a big case. The judge presiding over   the trial happens to be someone you knew from law school. The two of you were rather friendly back then, but now, decades later, it seems that your old friend barely remembers you. You’re quite sure that if you were to talk to him over lunch, you could jog his memory and he would begin to see you as an old buddy, which would be very good for your work on this case. It’s illegal for judges and lawyers working on the same case to meet socially. Is it appropriate for you to meet with this judge socially in order to help you win your case?
a1: it would be a violation of the rules of professional conduct for lawyers, which prohibit lawyers from engaging in ex parte communications with judges. ex parte communications are communications between a lawyer and a judge that are not known to or observed by the other party or parties to the case. such communications can give the lawyer an unfair advantage in the case.

title: Taxes
q0: You are the owner of a small business trying to make ends meet.   It occurs to you that you could lower your taxes by pretending that some of your personal expenses are business expenses. title: Standard Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there is a single patient. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to avoid the deaths of these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three patients. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the single patient, causing his death. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: the utilitarian approach would argue that the greatest good for the greatest number should be the guiding principle in this situation. since hitting the switch will save the lives of three patients while only causing the death of one, it is the morally correct course of action.

title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. Once you figure out which substance is the vaccine you can use it to save millions of lives. You have with you two people who are under your care, and the only way to identify the vaccine is to inject each of these people with one of the two substances. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of these people with a deadly injection in order to identify a vaccine that will save millions of lives?
a1: the reason is that the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the cost of one human life. in this case, the benefit is saving millions of lives, while the cost is the death of a single person. therefore, it is morally justifiable to kill one person in order to save many others.

title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?

title: Preventing the Spread 2
q0: You are a waiter. You overhear one of your customers say that he   is about to go to jail and that in his last forty-eight hours of freedom he plans to infect as many people as possible with HIV. You know him well enough to know that he is telling the truth and that he has access to many potential victims. You happen to know that he has a very strong allergy to poppy seeds. If he eats even one he will go into convulsions and have to be hospitalized. for at least forty-eight hours. Is it appropriate for you to cause this man to have a serious allergy attack in order to prevent him from spreading HIV?
a1: there are a few reasons why this would not be appropriate. first, it is not clear that causing the man to have an allergic reaction would actually stop him from spreading hiv. he may still be able to infect other people even if he is hospitalized. second, even if causing the man to have an allergic reaction would stop him from spreading hiv, it would be a very extreme measure to take and could potentially do more harm than good. the man could have a severe reaction to the poppy seeds and need to be hospitalized for an extended period of time, during which he would not be able to infect other people with hiv. however, the man could also suffer permanent health complications as a result of the allergy attack, which could outweigh the benefits of preventing him from spreading hiv.

title: Bomb 2
q0: You are negotiating with a powerful and determined terrorist who is about to   set off a bomb in a crowded area. Your one advantage is that you have his teenage son in your custody. There is only one thing that you can do to stop him from detonating his bomb, which will kill thousands of people if detonated. To stop him, you must contact him over the satellite hook-up that he has established and, in front of the camera, break one of his son’s arms and then threaten to break the other one if he does not give himself up. Is it appropriate for you to break the terrorist’s son’s arm in order to prevent the terrorist from killing thousands of people with his bomb?
a1: sacrificing the terrorist's son's arm for the greater good of saving thousands of lives is justified.

title: Environmental Policy B2
q0: You are a member of a government legislature. The legislature is deciding between   two different policies concerning environmental hazards. Policy A has a 90% chance of causing no deaths at all and has a 10% chance of causing 1000 deaths. Policy B has a 88% chance of causing no deaths and a 12% chance of causing 10 deaths. Is it appropriate for you to vote for Policy A over Policy B?
a1: the expected value of a policy is the sum of the probabilities of each outcome multiplied by the value of that outcome.   the expected value of policy A is 0.9(0) + 0.1(1000) = 900 the expected value of policy B is 0.88(0) + 0.12(10) = 120  policy B is superior to policy A because it has a lower expected value. this means that, on average, policy B will result in fewer deaths than policy A.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Illegal Lunch
q0: You are a lawyer working on a big case. The judge presiding over   the trial happens to be someone you knew from law school. title: Guarded Speedboat

title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. Once you figure out which substance is the vaccine you can use it to save millions of lives. You have with you two people who are under your care, and the only way to identify the vaccine is to inject each of these people with one of the two substances. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of these people with a deadly injection in order to identify a vaccine that will save millions of lives?
a1: the ends justify the means. in this case, the end goal is to save millions of lives, and the means is to kill one person. while it is tragic that someone has to die in order to achieve this goal, it is still the best course of action, all things considered.

title: Smother for dollars
q0: You are in hospital lounge waiting to visit a sick friend. A young   man sitting next to you explains that his father is very ill. The doctors believe that he has a week to live at most. title: Hired Rapist
q0: You have been dissatisfied with your marriage for several years. It is your   distinct impression that your wife no longer appreciates you. You remember how she appreciated you years ago when you took care of her after she was mugged. You devise the following plan to regain your wife’s affection. You will hire a man to break into your house while you are away. This man will tie up your wife and rape her. You, upon hearing the horrible news, will return swiftly to her side, to take care of her and comfort her, and she will once again appreciate you. Is it appropriate for you to hire a man to rape your wife so that she will appreciate you as you comfort her?

You know him well enough to know that he is telling the truth and that he has access to many potential victims. You happen to know that he has a very strong allergy to poppy seeds. If he eats even one he will go into convulsions and have to be hospitalized. for at least forty-eight hours. Is it appropriate for you to cause this man to have a serious allergy attack in order to prevent him from spreading HIV?
a1: the man's plans pose a serious threat to public health, and it is therefore justifiable to take measures to stop him from carrying them out. even though causing an allergy attack may seem like a harsh measure, it is ultimately more humane than allowing him to infect others with a deadly disease.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Vaccine Policy
q0: You work for the Bureau of Health, a government agency. You are deciding   whether or not your agency should encourage the use of a certain recently developed vaccine. The vast majority of people who take the vaccine develop an immunity to a certain deadly disease, but a very small number of people who take the vaccine will actually get the disease that the vaccine is designed to prevent. All the available evidence, which is very strong, suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to direct your agency to encourage the use of this vaccine in order to promote national health?
a1: the available evidence suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. therefore, it is in the best interest of public health to encourage the use of the vaccine.

title: Plant Transport
q0: You are bringing home a number of plants from a store that is   about two miles from your home. The trunk of your car, which you’ve lined with plastic to catch the mud from the plants, will hold most of the plants you’ve purchased. You could bring all the plants home in one trip, but this would require putting some of the plants in the back seat as well as in the trunk. By putting some of the plants in the back seat you will ruin your fine leather upholstery which would cost thousands of dollars to replace. Would you make two trips home in order to avoid ruining the upholstery of your car?
a1: better to make two troops than risk damaging my car and paying for costly repairs.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Three-for-Seven Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there are seven patients. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to save these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three people. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the seven patients, causing their deaths. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: by doing so, you would be causing the deaths of seven other patients. it is not morally permissible to cause the death of one person in order to save the life of another.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. title: Crying Baby
q0: Enemy soldiers have taken over your village. They have orders to kill all   remaining civilians. You and some of your townspeople have sought refuge in the cellar of a large house. Outside you hear the voices of soldiers who have come to search the house for valuables. Your baby begins to cry loudly. You cover his mouth to block the sound. If you remove your hand from his mouth his crying will summon the attention of the soldiers who will kill you, your child, and the others hiding out in the cellar. To save yourself and the others you must smother your child to death. Is it appropriate for you to smother your child in order to save yourself and the other townspeople?
a1: the answer to this question depends on the individual situation and the values of the person making the decision. if the person values their own life and the lives of the other townspeople more than the life of their child, then they may choose to smother their child in order to save themselves and the others. however, if the person values the life of their child more than their own life and the lives of the other townspeople, then they may choose not to smother their child, even if it means that they and the others will be killed.
question: Do you think the blue character involved in this dialogue was an artificial intelligence?

title: Reversed Turnips
q0: You are a farm worker driving a turnip-harvesting machine. You are approaching two   diverging paths. By choosing the path on the left you will harvest thirty bushels of turnips.
